ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Prerequisites/Preconditions] This protocol assumes the client has previously logged on to the message store, as specified in [MS-OXCSTOR] section 3.1.4.1, and has acquired a handle to the Server object on which it is going to operate.
[In Prerequisites/Preconditions] Methods to open the object and acquire a handle are dependent on the type of object.
[In Prerequisites/Preconditions] For details about Message objects and Attachment objects, see [MS-OXCMSG].
[In Prerequisites/Preconditions] For details about Folder objects, see [MS-OXCFOLD].
[In Prerequisites/Preconditions] For details about Logon objects, see [MS-OXCSTOR].
[In Prerequisites/Preconditions] Details about Stream objects are specified in this document.
[In Named Properties] A client can create its own custom property for an object by defining a named property.
[In Named Properties] A named property has a dynamic property ID that is assigned by the server.
[In Named Properties] A mapping of named properties to property IDs is provided by the server.

[In Transport] The ROP request buffers and ROP response buffers specified by this protocol are sent to and received by the server by using the underlying Remote Operations (ROP) List and Encoding Protocol, as specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In Common Object Properties] The properties specified in section 2.2.1.1 through section 2.2.1.9 are present on all objects.
[In Common Object Properties] A property that is specified as "read-only for the client" can be set only by the server.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R15, MS-OXCPRPT_R25, MS-OXCPRPT_R853, MS-OXCPRPT_R855, MS-OXCPRPT_R857, MS-OXCPRPT_R859, MS-OXCPRPT_R863.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In PidTagAccess Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagAccess Property] The PidTagAccess property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.505) indicates the operations available to the client for the object.
[In PidTagAccess Property] The value is a bitwise-OR of zero or more values[0x00000001,0x00000002,0x00000004,0x00000008,0x00000010,0x00000020] from the following table.
[In PidTagAccess Property] This property is read-only for the client.
[In PidTagAccess Property] If the value is 0x00000001,it indicates the meaning is Modify.
[In PidTagAccess Property] If the value is 0x00000002,it indicates the meaning is Read.
[In PidTagAccess Property] If the value is 0x00000004,it indicates the meaning is Delete.
[In PidTagAccess Property] If the value is 0x00000008, it indicates the meaning is Create hierarchy table.
[In PidTagAccess Property] If the value is 0x00000010, it indicates the meaning is Create contents table.
[In PidTagAccess Property] If the value is 0x00000020, it indicates the meaning is Create associated contents table.
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] The PidTagAccessLevel property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.507) indicates the client's access level to the object.
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] This property does not apply to Folder objects.
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] This property does not apply to Logon objects.
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] This value of this property MUST be one of the values in the following table. [0x00000000, 0x00000001].
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] This property is read-only for the client.
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] If the value is 0x00000000, it indicates the meaning is Read-Only.
[In PidTagAccessLevel Property] If the value is 0x00000001, it indicates the meaning is Modify.
[In PidTagChangeKey Property] Type: PtypBinary ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagChangeKey Property] The PidTagChangeKey property ([MS-OXCFXICS] section 2.2.1.2.7) contains a global identifier indicating the last change to the object.
[In PidTagChangeKey Property] This property is read-only for clients.
[In PidTagCreationTime Property] Type: PtypTime ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagCreationTime Property] The PidTagCreationTime property ([MS-OXCMSG] section 2.2.2.3) contains the time that the object was created in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).
[In PidTagCreationTime Property] This property is read-only for clients.
[In PidTagLastModifierName Property] Type: PtypString ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagLastModifierName Property] The PidTagLastModifierName property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.767) contains the name of the last mail user to modify the object.
[In PidTagLastModifierName Property] This property does not apply to Folder objects.
[In PidTagLastModifierName Property] This property does not apply to Logon objects.
[In PidTagLastModifierName Property] This property is read-only for clients.
[In PidTagLastModificationTimeProperty] Type: PtypTime ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagLastModificationTime Property] The PidTagLastModificationTime property ([MS-OXCMSG] section 2.2.2.2) contains the time of the last modification to the object in UTC.
[In PidTagLastModificationTime Property] This property is read-only for clients.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] Type: PtypInteger32. ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagObjectType Property] The PidTagObjectType property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.814) indicates the type of Server object.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] This property does not apply to Folder objects.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] This property does not apply to Logon objects.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] The value of this property MUST be one of the values in the following table[0x00000001,0x00000002,0x00000004,0x00000005,0x00000006,0x00000007,0x00000008].
[In PidTagObjectType Property] This property is read-only for the client.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] If the value is 0x00000001,it indicates the meaning is Store object.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] If the value is 0x00000002,it indicates the meaning is Address Book object.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] If the value is 0x00000004,it indicates the meaning is address book container.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] If the value is 0x00000005,it indicates the meaning is Message object.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] If the value is 0x00000006,it indicates the meaning is mail user.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] If the value is 0x00000007,it indicates the meaning is Attachment object.
[In PidTagObjectType Property] If the value is 0x00000008, it indicates the meaning is distribution list.
[In PidTagRecordKey Property] Type: PtypBinary ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagRecordKey Property] The PidTagRecordKey property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.911) contains a unique binary-comparable identifier for a specific object
[In PidTagRecordKey Property] Whenever a copy of an object is created, the server generates a new identifier for the copied object.
[In PidTagRecordKey Property] This property does not apply to Folder objects.
[In PidTagRecordKey Property] This property does not apply to Logon objects.
[In PidTagRecordKey Property] This property is read-only for the client.
[In PidTagSearchKey Property] Type: PtypBinary ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1).
[In PidTagSearchKey Property] The PidTagSearchKey property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.998) contains a unique binary-comparable key that identifies an object for a search.
[In PidTagSearchKey Property] Whenever a copy of an object is created, the key is also copied from the original object.
[In PidTagSearchKey Property] This property does not apply to Folder objects.
[In PidTagSearchKey Property] This property does not apply to Logon objects.
[In PidTagSearchKey Property] This property is read-only for clients.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP] The RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.3) queries for and returns the values of properties specified in the PropertyTags field.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP] Message objects are supported for this operation [RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP].
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP] Folder objects are supported for this operation [RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP].
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP] Attachment objects are supported for this operation [RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP].
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP] Logon objects are supported for this operation [RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP].
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].

[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields[PropertySizeLimit, WantUnicode, PropertyTagCount] for the RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.3.1).
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: An integer that specifies the maximum size allowed for a property value.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R62, MS-OXCPRPT_R63.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: If this value is zero, the property values are limited only by the size of the ROP response buffer.

[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: If this value is nonzero, the property values are limited both by the size of the ROP response buffer and by the value of the PropertySizeLimit field.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] WantUnicode: 2 bytes Boolean value.

[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] WantUnicode: A Boolean value that is nonzero if the string properties that are requested with PtypUnspecified ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) as the property type are to be encoded in the Unicode format in the ROP response buffer.

[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] WantUnicode: If WantUnicode is set to zero, the string properties that are requested with PtypUnspecified as the property type are to be encoded in multibyte character set (MBCS) format.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTagCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTagCount: An integer that specifies the number of property tags contained in the PropertyTags field.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTags (variable): An array of PropertyTag structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.9).
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTags: Each structure contains the property tag of a property for which the client is requesting the value.
[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.3.2).

[In RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP Response Buffer] RowData (variable): A PropertyRow structure ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.8.1) that contains the values of the properties specified in the ROP request buffer.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] The RopGetPropertiesAll ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.4) queries for and returns all of the property tags and values of properties that have been set.

[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] The client can create an equivalent duplicate of a Message object by copying only these properties, without considering its attachments table and recipient table that might be on the object.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] is valid on Logon objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetPropertiesAll ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.4.1).
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: An integer that specifies the maximum size allowed for a property value.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R84, MS-OXCPRPT_R85.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: If this value[PropertySizeLimit] is zero, the property values are only limited by the size of the ROP[RopGetPropertiesAll] response buffer.

[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] PropertySizeLimit: If this value is nonzero, the property values are limited both by the size of the ROP response buffer and by the value of the PropertySizeLimit field.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] WantUnicode: 2 bytes Boolean value.

[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] WantUnicode: A Boolean value that is nonzero if string properties that are requested with PtypUnspecified ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) as the property type are to be encoded in the Unicode format in the ROP response buffer.

[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Request Buffer] WantUnicode: If WantUnicode is set to zero, the string properties that are requested with PtypUnspecified as the property type are to be encoded in MBCS format.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetPropertiesAll ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.4.2).
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Response Buffer] PropertyValueCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Response Buffer] PropertyValueCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements in the PropertyValues field.

[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Response Buffer] PropertyValues (variable): An array of TaggedPropertyValue structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.4) containing all property tags and property values on the queried object.

[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Response Buffer] PropertyValues: If a value is larger than the available space in the ROP response buffer, the type MUST be PtypErrorCode ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) with a value of NotEnoughMemory ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.2).

[In RopGetPropertiesAll ROP Response Buffer] PropertyValues: If the property value is larger than the size specified in the PropertySizeLimit field of the ROP request buffer, the type MUST be PtypErrorCode ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) with a value of NotEnoughMemory ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.2).
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP] The RopGetPropertiesList ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.5) queries for and returns all of the property tags for properties that have been set on an object.
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP] This operation[RopGetPropertiesList ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP] This operation[RopGetPropertiesList ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP] This operation[RopGetPropertiesList ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP] This operation[RopGetPropertiesList ROP] is valid on Logon objects.
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP Request Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopGetPropertiesList ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.5.1).
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetPropertiesList ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.5.2).
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP Response Buffer] PropertyTagCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP Response Buffer] PropertyTagCount: An integer that specifies the number of property tags contained in the PropertyTags field.
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP Response Buffer] PropertyTags (variable): An array of PropertyTag structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.9).
[In RopGetPropertiesList ROP Response Buffer] PropertyTags: The array contains a property tag for each property currently set on the object.
[In RopSetProperties ROP] The RopSetProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.6) updates the specified properties on an object.
[In RopSetProperties ROP] This operation [RopSetProperties ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopSetProperties ROP] This operation [RopSetProperties ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopSetProperties ROP] This operation [RopSetProperties ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopSetProperties ROP] This operation [RopSetProperties ROP] is valid on Logon objects.
[In RopSetProperties ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSetProperties ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSetProperties ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopSetProperties ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.6.1).
[In RopSetProperties ROP Request Buffer] propertyValueSize: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopSetProperties ROP Request Buffer] ] propertyValueSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes in the PropertyValueCount field plus the number of bytes in the PropertyValues field.
[In RopSetProperties ROP Request Buffer] propertyValueCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopSetProperties ROP Request Buffer] propertyValueCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyValues field.
[In RopSetProperties ROP Request Buffer] propertyValues (variable): An array of TaggedPropertyValue structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.4).
[In RopSetProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyValues: Each structure specifies a property that is to be updated.
[In RopSetProperties ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopSetProperties ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.6.2).
[In RopSetProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopSetProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyProblems field.
[In RopSetProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblems (variable): An array of PropertyProblem structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.7).
[In RopSetProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblems: Each structure specifies a property that was not set and the reason that the property was not set.

[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] The RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.7) has the same fields and works the same way as the RopSetProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.6).

[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] [The RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.7) has the same fields and works the same way as the RopSetProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.6)] with the exception that when this ROP is used to set properties on a Folder object, the updated properties will not undergo folder replication.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] For information about folder replication, see [MS-OXCSTOR] section 3.1.4.3.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] On all other objects [Message objects, Attachment objects and Logon objects], the RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP works the same way as the RopSetProperties ROP.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] The server MUST modify the value of the properties of the object.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] For Message objects, the new value of the properties MUST be made available immediately when using the same handle.

[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] If the client uses the same object handle in a RopGetPropertiesAll ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.4) to read those same properties, the modified value MUST be returned.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] However, the modified value MUST NOT be persisted to the database until a successful RopSaveChangesMessage ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.6.3) is issued.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] For Attachment objects, the new value of the properties MUST be made available immediately when using the same handle.

[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] However, the modified value MUST NOT be persisted to the database until a successful RopSaveChangesAttachment ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.6.15) followed by a successful RopSaveChangesMessage ROP is issued.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] For Logon objects, the new value of the properties MUST be persisted immediately without requiring another ROP to commit it.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] This ROP is supported for Message objects.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] This ROP is supported for Folder objects.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] This ROP is supported for Attachment objects.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] This ROP is supported for Logon objects.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.7.1).

[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP Request Buffer] The fields of the RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.7.1) are the same as those of the RopSetProperties ROP request buffer (section 2.2.5.1).
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.7.2).

[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP Response Buffer] The fields of the RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.7.2) are the same as those of the RopSetProperties ROP response buffer (section 2.2.5.2).
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopSetPropertiesNoReplicate ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyProblems field.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP] The RopDeleteProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.8) removes the specified properties from an object.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP] This operation [RopDeleteProperties ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP] This operation [RopDeleteProperties ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP] This operation [RopDeleteProperties ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP] This operation [RopDeleteProperties ROP] is valid on Logon objects.
[In RopDeleteProperties] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopDeleteProperties] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopDeleteProperties ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.8.1).
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTagCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTagCount: An integer that specifies the number of property tags contained in the PropertyTags field.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTags (variable): An array of PropertyTag structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.9).
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTags (variable): Each structure specifies the property tag of a property that the client is deleting.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopDeleteProperties ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.8.2).
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblemCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblemCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyProblems field.
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblems (variable): An array of PropertyProblem structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.7).
[In RopDeleteProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblems: Each structure specifies a property that was not deleted and the reason that the property was not deleted.

[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP] The RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.9) has the same fields and works the same way as the RopDeleteProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.8).

[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP] [The RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.9) has the same fields and works the same way as the RopDeleteProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.8)] with the exception that when this ROP is used to delete properties from a Folder object, the deleted properties will not undergo folder replication.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP] For information about folder replication, see [MS-OXCSTOR] section 3.1.4.3.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP] On all other objects [Message objects, Attachment objects and Logon objects], the RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP works the same way as RopDeleteProperties.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] If the server returns success it MUST NOT have a valid value to return to a client that asks for the value of this property.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] The server MUST remove the value of the property from the object.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] For Message objects, the properties MUST be removed immediately when using the same handle.

[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] In other words, if the client uses the same handle to read those same properties using the RopGetPropertiesSpecific ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.3), the properties MUST be deleted.

[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] In other words, if the client uses the same handle to read those same properties using the RopGetPropertiesAll ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.4), the properties MUST be deleted.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] However, the deleted properties MUST NOT be persisted to the database until a successful RopSaveChangesMessage ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.6.3) is issued.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] For Attachment objects, the properties MUST be removed immediately when using the same handle.

[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] However, the deleted properties MUST NOT be persisted to the database until a successful RopSaveChangesAttachment ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.6.15) and a successful RopSaveChangesMessage ROP are issued, in that order.
[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate] For Logon objects, the properties MUST be removed immediately without requiring another ROP to commit the change.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.9.2).

[In RopDeletePropertiesNoReplicate ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblems (variable): An array of PropertyProblem structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.7).
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP] The RopQueryNamedProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.10) queries an object for all the named properties.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP] This operation is valid on Logon objects.<1>

[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP] This operation is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP] This operation is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopQueryNamedProperties ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.10.1).
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] QueryFlags (1 byte): A set of bits that control which type of named property is returned.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] QueryFlags: The valid bits for this field are listed in the following table.[NoStrings, NoIds]
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] QueryFlags: The NoStrings value is 0x01.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] QueryFlags: NoStrings:Named properties that have a property name identifier MUST NOT be included in the response.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] QueryFlags: The NoIds value is 0x02.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] QueryFlags: NoIds:Named properties that have a long ID (LID) MUST NOT be included in the response.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] HasGuid: 1 byte Boolean value.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] HasGuid: A Boolean value that is nonzero if the PropertyGuid field is included in the request.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] HasGUID: If the value is zero, the PropertyGUID field MUST NOT be present.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyGuid: 16 bytes GUID.

[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyGuid: A GUID that specifies the property set of properties to be returned. If this field is present, only named properties with a property set matching the GUID are returned in a successful response.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyGUID: This field MUST be present if the HasGuid field is set to nonzero.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopQueryNamedProperties ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.10.2).
[In IdCount] IdCount: 2 byte integer.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] IdCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyIds field.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyIds (variable): An array of 16-bit integers, each of which is a property ID.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyIds: The number of integers contained in the array MUST equal the value specified in the IdCount field.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: The array MUST contain one property ID for each of the named properties specified in the PropertyNames field.
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyNames (variable): An array of PropertyName structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.6.1).
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyNames : Each structure contains the details about a named property
[In RopQueryNamedProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyNames:The entries in this list MUST match the order of the entries in the PropertyIds field, and the number of entries MUST be equal.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] The RopCopyProperties ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.11) copies or moves one or more properties from one object to another.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] It can be used for replying to and forwarding Message objects in which only some of the properties from the original Message object travel with the reply or forwarded copy.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] Also, the source and destination object MUST be of the same type.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] This operation [RopCopyProperties ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] This operation [RopCopyProperties ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] This operation [RopCopyProperties ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCopyProperties ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopCopyProperties ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.11.1).
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronous: 1 byte Boolean value.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronous: A Boolean value that indicates whether the ROP is to be processed synchronously or asynchronously.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronous: If this field is set to zero, then the server performs the ROP[RopCopyProperties] synchronously.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronous: If this field is set to nonzero, the ROP is processed either synchronously or asynchronously.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags (1 byte): A set of bits that control options for moving or copying properties.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: The valid bits are listed in the following table. [0x01,0x02]
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: These bits SHOULD NOT<2> be combined.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R86502, MS-OXCPRPT_R86701.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: The Move value is 0x01.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: If this bit[bit 0x01] is set, properties are moved
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: otherwise [If this bit is not set to 0x01], properties are copied.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: The NoOverwrite value is 0x02.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: NoOverwrite: If this bit[bit 0x02] is set, properties that already have a value on the destination object will not be overwritten;
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: NoOverwrite: otherwise(If this bit is not set to 0x02), they [properties that already have a value on the destination object] are overwritten.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] propertyTagCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] propertyTagCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyTags field.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] ] PropertyTags (variable): An array of PropertyTag structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.9).
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTags: Each structure contains the property tag of a property to be copied or moved.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopCopyProperties ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.11.2).
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyProblems field.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblemCount: This field MUST NOT be present if the ReturnValue field is set to NullDestinationObject (0x00000503).
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblems (variable): An array of PropertyProblem structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.7).
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblems: Each structure specifies a property that was not copied or moved and the reason that the property was not copied or moved.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblems: This field MUST NOT be present if the ReturnValue field is set to NullDestinationObject (0x00000503).
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: 4 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: An integer that specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the destination Server object is stored.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: The DestHandleIndex field MUST be set to the value of the DestHandleIndex field of the ROP request buffer.
[In RopCopyProperties ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: The DestHandleIndex field MUST NOT be present if the ReturnValue field is set to any value other than NullDestinationObject (0x00000503).
[In RopCopyTo ROP] The RopCopyTo ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.12) is used to copy or move all but a specified few properties from a source object to a destination object.
[In RopCopyTo ROP] This operation [RopCopyTo ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopCopyTo ROP] This operation [RopCopyTo ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopCopyTo ROP] This operation [RopCopyTo ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopCopyTo ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCopyTo ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopCopyTo ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.12.1).
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronous: 1 byte Boolean value.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronous]WantAsynchronous: A Boolean value that indicates whether the ROP is to be processed synchronously or asynchronously.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronous: If this field is set to zero, this ROP [RopCopyTo ROP] is processed synchronously.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] WantAsynchronou:] If this field is set to nonzero, this ROP [RopCopyTo ROP] is processed either synchronously or asynchronously.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] WantSubObjects: WantSubObjects (1 byte): A Boolean value .
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] WantSubObjects: If WantSubObjects is nonzero then sub-objects MUST also be copied.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] WantSubObjects: Otherwise[If WantSubObjects is zero] they[sub-objects] are not[copied].
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags (1 byte).
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: A set of bits that control options for moving or copying properties.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: The valid bits are listed in the following table[0x01, 0x02].
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: These bits SHOULD NOT<3> be combined.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R18402, MS-OXCPRPT_R86702.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: The Move value is 0x01.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: Move: If this bit [bit 0x01] is set, properties are moved.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R86707.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: Move: otherwise(If this bit is not set to 0x01), properties are copied.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: The NoOverwrite value is 0x02.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: NoOverwrite: If this bit[bit 0x02] is set, properties that already have a value on the destination object will not be overwritten;
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] CopyFlags: otherwise[If this bit is not set to 0x02], they [properties that already have a value on the destination object] are overwritten.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] ExcludedTagCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] ExcludedTagCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the ExcludedTags field.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] ExcludedTags: An array of PropertyTag structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.9).
[In RopCopyTo ROP Request Buffer] ExcludedTags: Each structure contains the property tag of a property that MUST NOT be copied or moved as part of this operation.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopCopyTo ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.12.2).
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblemCount: An integer that specifies the number of elements contained in the PropertyProblems field.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblemCount: This field MUST NOT be present if the ReturnValue field is set to NullDestinationObject (0x00000503).
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblems (variable): An array of PropertyProblem structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.7).
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] propertyProblems: Each structure specifies a property that was not copied or moved and the reason that the property was not copied or moved.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] PropertyProblems: This field MUST NOT be present if the ReturnValue field is set to NullDestinationObject (0x00000503).
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex (4 bytes): An integer.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: An integer that specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the destination Server object is stored.
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: The DestHandleIndex field MUST be set to the value of the DestHandleIndex field of the ROP request buffer
[In RopCopyTo ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: The DestHandleIndex field MUST NOT be present if the ReturnValue field is set to any value other than NullDestinationObject (0x00000503).

[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] The RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.1) maps abstract, client-defined named properties to concrete 16-bit property IDs (of which 15 bits are significant).
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] A fully formed property tag is built from the 16-bit property ID and a 16-bit type code.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] This operation [RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] is valid on Logon objects.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.1.1).
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] Flags (1 byte): An integer.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] Flags: An integer that specifies whether to create a new entry.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R628, MS-OXCPRPT_R62801.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] Flags: This field is set to 0x02 to request that a new entry be created for each named property that is not found in the existing mapping table;

[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] Flags: This field is set to 0x00 otherwise[If not request a new entry to be created for each named property that is not found in the existing mapping table].
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] propertyNameCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] propertyNameCount: An integer that specifies the number of PropertyName structures contained in the PropertyNames field.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] PropertyNameCount: A value of zero indicates that the client is querying the complete list of registered named properties
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] propertyNames (variable): An array of PropertyName structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.6).
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Request Buffer] PropertyNames: Each structure specifies a named property to be mapped to a property ID.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.1.2).
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIdCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIdCount: An integer that specifies the number of property IDs contained in the PropertyIds field.

[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIdCount: The value of this field MUST be equal to the value of the PropertyNameCount field of the ROP request buffer unless the value of the PropertyNameCount field is zero.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIdCount: In that case(PropertyNameCount field is zero), the value MUST be equal to the total number of registered named properties.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] propertyIds (variable): An array of 16-bit integers.

[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: Each integer is a property ID that is mapped from a named property that is specified in the PropertyNames field of the ROP request buffer
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: If a named property cannot be mapped, the associated entry in the PropertyIds field MUST be 0x0000.

[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: The order of property IDs in this array MUST match the order of the named properties specified in the PropertyNames field of the ROP request buffer.

[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: Reasons a name couldn't be mapped include: Use of the PS_MAPI namespace and not specifying 0x00 for the Kind field of the PropertyName structure ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.6.1).

[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: Reasons a name couldn't be mapped include:The name wasn't found in the mapping table and the Flags field of the ROP request buffer was not set to 0x02.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: Reasons a name couldn't be mapped include: The user does not have permission to register new named properties.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: Reasons a name couldn't be mapped include: The user has reached an artificial quota of named properties imposed by the server.
[In RopGetPropertyIdsFromNames ROP Response Buffer] PropertyIds: Reasons a name couldn't be mapped include: The user has reached the hard limit of 32,767 registered named properties.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] The RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.2) maps concrete property IDs to abstract, client-defined named properties
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] This operation [RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] This operation [RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] This operation [RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] This operation [RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] is valid on Logon objects.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] Property IDs for named properties are identified by having their most significant bit set (0x8000).
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] The client can request to map non-named property IDs (IDs with the most significant bit unset) into names.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] The PS_MAPI namespace is used for mapping non-named property IDs into names.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.2.1).
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Request Buffer] propertyIdCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Request Buffer] propertyIdCount: An integer that specifies the number of 16-bit property IDs contained in the PropertyIds field.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Request Buffer] PropertyIds (variable): An array of 16-bit integers.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Request Buffer] PropertyIds: Each integer is a property ID to be mapped to a named property.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Request Buffer] PropertyIds: The client can pass property ID values less than 0x8000.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Request Buffer] PropertyIds: These values will be mapped into names in the PS_MAPI namespace ([MS-OXPROPS] section 1.3.2).
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.2.2).
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Response Buffer] PropertyNameCount: 2 bytes integer.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Response Buffer] propertyNameCount: An integer that specifies the number of structures contained in the PropertyNames field.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Response Buffer] PropertyNameCount: This value MUST be equal to the value of the PropertyIdCount field of the ROP request buffer.
[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Response Buffer] PropertyNames (variable): An array of PropertyName structures ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.6).

[In RopGetNamesFromPropertyIds ROP Response Buffer] PropertyNames: Each structure specifies a named property that is mapped from a property ID that is specified in the PropertyIds field of the ROP request buffer.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] The RopOpenStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.1) opens a property as a Stream object.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] The RopOpenStream ROP enabling the client to perform various streaming operations on the property.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] This operation [RopOpenStream ROP] is valid on Message objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] This operation [RopOpenStream ROP] is valid on Folder objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] This operation [RopOpenStream ROP] is valid on Attachment objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] Only single-valued PtypBinary, PtypObject, and PtypString type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) are supported for Attachment objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R25502, MS-OXCPRPT_R25503, MS-OXCPRPT_R25505.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopOpenStream ROP] Single-valued PtypBinary type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Attachment objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] Single-valued PtypObject type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Attachment objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] Single-valued PtypString type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Attachment objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopOpenStream ROP] Only single-valued PtypString8 type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Attachment objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] Only single-valued PtypBinary, PtypObject, and PtypString type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) are supported for Message objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCPRPT_R25506, MS-OXCPRPT_R25507, MS-OXCPRPT_R25509.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopOpenStream ROP] Single-valued PtypBinary type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Message objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] Single-valued PtypObject type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Message objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] Single-valued PtypString type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Message objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] Only single-valued PtypString8 type properties ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1) is supported for Message objects.
[In RopOpenStream ROP]Only single-valued properties that are of the following types MUST be supported for Folder objects: PtypBinary.
[In RopOpenStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopOpenStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopOpenStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.1.1).
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTag (4 bytes): An integer.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTag: An integer that is the property tag of the property for which the client is opening the stream.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] PropertyTag: The format of a property tag is specified in [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.9.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags (1 byte): An integer.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: An integer that specifies the mode for opening the stream.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: The OpenModeFlags field MUST be set to one of the values in the following table.[0x00,0x01,0x02,0x03].
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: The ReadOnly value is 0x00.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: ReadOnly: Open the stream for read-only access.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: The ReadWrite value is 0x01.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: ReadWrite: Open the stream for read/write access.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: The Create value is 0x02.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: Create: Open a new stream. This mode will delete the current property value and open the stream for read/write access.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Request Buffer] OpenModeFlags: Create: This mode is required for a property that has not been set.
[In RopOpenStream ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopOpenStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.1.2).
[In RopOpenStream ROP Response Buffer]StreamSize (4 bytes).
[In RopOpenStream ROP Response Buffer]StreamSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes in the opened stream.
[In RopReadStream ROP] The RopReadStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.2) reads the stream of bytes from a Stream object.
[In RopReadStream ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R27800.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopReadStream ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopReadStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopReadStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopReadStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.2.1).
[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] ByteCount (2 bytes):An integer.
[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] ByteCount: An integer that specifies the maximum number of bytes to be read unless the value is 0xBABE
[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] ByteCount: In that case[The value of ByteCount is 0xBABE], the maximum number of bytes to be read is specified by the MaximumByteCount field.
[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] MaximumByteCount: 4 bytes integer.
[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] MaximumByteCount: An integer that specifies the maximum number of bytes to be read if the ByteCount field is set to 0xBABE.

[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] MaximumByteCount: Note that because MaximumByteCount can exceed the amount of data that can be returned in a single response buffer, the response can span multiple response buffers.
[In RopReadStream ROP Request Buffer] MaximumByteCount: This field MUST be present if and only if the value of the ByteCount field is 0xBABE.
[In RopReadStream ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopReadStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.2.2).
[In RopReadStream ROP Response Buffer] DataSize (2 bytes): An integer.
[In RopReadStream ROP Response Buffer] DataSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes in the Data field.
[In RopReadStream ROP Response Buffer] Data (variable): An array of bytes that constitute the data read from the stream.
[In RopReadStream ROP Response Buffer] Data: This field MUST contain exactly the number of bytes specified in the DataSize field.
[In RopWriteStream ROP] The RopWriteStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.3) writes the stream of bytes into a Stream object.
[In RopWriteStream ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R29801.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopWriteStream ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopWriteStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopWriteStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopWriteStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopWriteStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.3.1).
[In RopWriteStream ROP Request Buffer] DataSize (2 bytes): An integer.
[In RopWriteStream ROP Request Buffer] DataSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes in the Data field.
[In RopWriteStream ROP Request Buffer] Data (variable): An array of bytes that constitute the data to be written to the stream.
[In RopWriteStream ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopWriteStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.3.2).
[In RopWriteStream ROP Response Buffer] WrittenSize (2 bytes): An integer.
[In RopWriteStream ROP Response Buffer] WrittenSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes actually written to the stream.
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP] The RopWriteStreamExtended ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.4) writes the stream of bytes into a Stream object.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP] This operation [RopWriteStreamExtended] is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R30401003

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP] This operation [RopWriteStreamExtended] is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopWriteStreamExtended ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.4.1).
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP Request Buffer] DataSize (2 bytes): An integer that specifies the number of bytes in the Data field.
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP Request Buffer] Data (variable): An array of bytes that constitute the data to be written to the stream.
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopWriteStreamExtended ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.4.2).
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP Response Buffer] WrittenSize (4 bytes): An integer.
[In RopWriteStreamExtended ROP Response Buffer] WrittenSize (4 bytes): An integer that specifies the number of bytes actually written to the stream.
[In RopCommitStream ROP] The RopCommitStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.5) ensures that any changes made to a Stream object are persisted in storage.
[In RopCommitStream ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R30601.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopCommitStream ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopCommitStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCommitStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCommitStream ROP Request Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopCommitStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.5.1).
[In RopCommitStream ROP Response Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopCommitStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.5.2).
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP] The RopGetStreamSize ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.6) retrieves the size of the stream.
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R30901.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetStreamSize ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP Request Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopGetStreamSize ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.6.1).
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetStreamSize ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.6.2).
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP Response Buffer] StreamSize (4 bytes): An integer .
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP Response Buffer] StreamSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes in the stream.
[In RopGetStreamSize ROP Response Buffer] The maximum allowed stream size is 2^31 bytes.
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP] The RopSetStreamSize ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.7) sets the size of a stream.
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R32301.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopSetStreamSize ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP] This ROP is not required prior to writing to the stream.
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopSetStreamSize ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.7.1).
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP Request Buffer] StreamSize (8 bytes): An integer.
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP Request Buffer] StreamSize: An integer that specifies the size, in bytes, of the stream.
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP Request Buffer] StreamSize: The maximum allowed stream size is 2^31 bytes.
[In RopSetStreamSize ROP Response Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopSetStreamSize ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.7.2).
[In RopSeekStream ROP] RopSeekStream sets the seek pointer to a new location.
[In RopSeekStream ROP] The new location is relative to either the beginning of the stream, the end of the stream, or the current seek pointer, which is specified by Origin parameter.
[In RopSeekStream ROP] This ROP can also be used to get the location of the current seek pointer by setting the Origin field to 0x01 and the Offset field to zero.
[In RopSeekStream ROP] This ROP is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R33101.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopSeekStream ROP] This ROP is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopSeekStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSeekStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopSeekStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.8.1).
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Origin (1 byte).: An integer.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Origin: An integer that specifies the point of origin for the seek pointer.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Origin: The Origin field MUST be set to one of the values in the following table.[0x00,0x01,0x02].
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Origin: If the value is 0x00 ,The point of origin is the beginning of the stream.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Origin: If the value is 0x01, The point of origin is the location of the current seek pointer.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Origin: If the value is 0x02 The point of origin is the end of the stream.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Offset (8 bytes).
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Offset: An integer that specifies the number of bytes that the seek pointer is to be offset from the origin.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Offset: The value can be positive.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Request Buffer] Offset: The value can be negative.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopSeekStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.8.2).
[In RopSeekStream ROP Response Buffer] NewPosition (8 bytes): An integer.
[In RopSeekStream ROP Response Buffer] NewPosition: An integer that specifies the new offset, in bytes, of the seek pointer from the beginning of the stream.

[In RopCopyToStream ROP] The RopCopyToStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.9) copies a specified number of bytes from the current seek pointer in the source stream to the current seek pointer in the destination stream.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R34301.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopCopyToStream ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCopyToStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopCopyToStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.9.1).
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Request Buffer] ByteCount: 8 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Request Buffer] ByteCount: An integer that specifies the number of bytes to be copied from the source stream to the destination stream.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopCopyToStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.9.2)..
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex (4 bytes): An integer.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex : An integer that specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the destination Server object is stored.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: The DestHandleIndex field MUST be set to the value of the DestHandleIndex field of the ROP request buffer.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] DestHandleIndex: The DestHandleIndex field MUST NOT be present if the ReturnValue field is set to any value other than NullDestinationObject (0x00000503).
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] ReadByteCount: 8 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] ReadByteCount: An integer that specifies the number of bytes read from the source stream.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] ReadByteCount: If the ReturnValue field is set to NullDestinationObject (0x00000503), the value of the ReadByteCount field is undefined.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] WrittenByteCount: 8 bytes integer.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] WrittenByteCount: An integer that specifies the number of bytes written to the destination stream.
[In RopCopyToStream ROP Response Buffer] WrittenByteCount: If the ReturnValue field is set to NullDestinationObject (0x00000503), the value of the WrittenByteCount field is undefined.
[In RopProgress ROP] The RopProgress ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.13) reports the progress status of an asynchronous operation.
[In RopProgress ROP] This ROP also can abort an in-progress operation if the WantCancel field is set to nonzero.
[In RopProgress ROP] This operation is valid on any object on which an asynchronous operation is used.
[In RopProgress ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopProgress ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopProgress ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopProgress ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.13.1).
[In RopProgress ROP Request Buffer] WantCancel (1 byte): A Boolean value.
[In RopProgress ROP Request Buffer] WantCancel: A Boolean value that is zero if the client wants the current operation to continue.
[In RopProgress ROP Request Buffer] WantCancel: The value is nonzero to request that the server cancel the operation.
[In RopProgress ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopProgress ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.13.2).
[In RopProgress ROP Response Buffer] CompletedTaskCount: 4 bytes integer.
[In RopProgress ROP Response Buffer] CompletedTaskCount: An integer that specifies the approximate number of tasks that the server has completed.
[In RopProgress ROP Response Buffer] TotalTaskCount: 4 bytes integer.
[In RopProgress ROP Response Buffer] TotalTaskCount: An integer that specifies the approximate number of tasks the server will complete for the entire operation.
[In RopProgress ROP Response Buffer] TotalTaskCount: The value of this field MUST be greater than or equal to the value of the CompletedTaskCount field.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP] The RopLockRegionStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.10) is used to lock a specified range of bytes in a Stream object.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R37401.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopLockRegionStream ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopLockRegionStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.10.1).
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionOffset (8 bytes): An unsigned 64-bit integer.

[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionOffset: An unsigned 64-bit integer that specifies the number of bytes from the beginning of the stream where the beginning of the region to be locked is located.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionSize (8 bytes): An unsigned 64-bit integer.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionSize: An unsigned 64-bit integer that specifies the size, in bytes, of the region to be locked.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags (4 bytes): A set of bits that control the read/write access to the locked region.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags: A set of bits that control the read/write access to the locked region.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags: The LockFlags field MUST be set to one of the values in the following table.[0x001,Any other value].

[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags: If the value is 0x001, indicates that if this lock is granted, the specified range of bytes can be opened and read any number of times, but writing to the locked range is prohibited except for the owner that was granted this lock.

[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags: If the value is any other value, indicates that if this lock is granted, reading and writing to the specified range of bytes is prohibited except by the owner that was granted this lock.
[In RopLockRegionStream ROP Response Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopLockRegionStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.10.2).
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP] The RopUnlockRegionStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.11) unlocks a specified range of bytes in a Stream object.
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP] This ROP is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R38103.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP] This ROP is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopUnlockRegionStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.11.1).
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionOffset (8 bytes): An unsigned 64-bit integer.

[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionOffset: An unsigned 64-bit integer that specifies the number of bytes from the beginning of the stream where the beginning of the region to be unlocked is located.
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionSize (8 bytes): An unsigned 64-bit integer.
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] RegionSize: An unsigned 64-bit integer that specifies the size, in bytes, of the region to be unlocked.
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags (4 bytes).
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags: A set of bits that control the read/write access to the locked region.
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags: The value of the LockFlags field MUST be one of the values specified in section 2.2.24.1. [0x001,Any other value]

[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Request Buffer] LockFlags: In addition, it MUST be set to the same value that was used in the RopLockRegionStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.10) that was used to lock the region of bytes.
[In RopUnlockRegionStream ROP Response Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopUnlockRegionStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.11.2).

[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP] The RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.12) is functionally equivalent to RopWriteStream ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.3) followed by RopCommitStream ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.5).
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R63201.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP] This ROP MUST NOT be used on a Stream object that is opened on a property of a Folder object
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.12.1).
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP Request Buffer] DataSize (2 bytes): An integer.
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP Request Buffer] DataSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes in the Data field.
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP Request Buffer] Data (variable): An array of bytes that constitute the data to be written and committed to the stream.
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.12.2).
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP Response Buffer] WrittenSize (2 bytes): An integer.
[In RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP Response Buffer] WrittenSize: An integer that specifies the number of bytes actually written and committed to the stream.
[In RopCloneStream ROP] The RopCloneStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.13) creates a new Stream object that is a clone of another Stream object.
[In RopCloneStream ROP] The cloned Stream object allows access to the same bytes but has a separate seek pointer
[In RopCloneStream ROP] This operation is valid only on Stream objects.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCPRPT_R39801.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopCloneStream ROP] This operation is valid on Stream objects.
[In RopCloneStream ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCloneStream ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopCloneStream ROP Request Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopCloneStream ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.13.1).
[In RopCloneStream ROP Response Buffer] This protocol adds no additional field details to the RopCloneStream ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.13.2).
[In Abstract Data Model] This section describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol.
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.

[In Abstract Data Model] This document [Property and Stream Object Protocol Specification] does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model as long as their external behavior is consistent with that described in this document.
[In Abstract Data Model] Changes to a property: There are two different models for persisting the new value of a property to the database
